candidates.title: Move all remaining tests to test suite
Move sg-eth-airdrop and vending minter tests into testing-suite
candidates.body:
PART 2
There are 3 PRs in this series: 
1) https://github.com/public-awesome/launchpad/pull/479  => Refactors the vending minter tests that will serve as the common core for other similar tests
2) https://github.com/public-awesome/launchpad/pull/483  => Create the test-suite folder where all tests will eventually go and move the two contracts affected most to the test-suite
3) https://github.com/public-awesome/launchpad/pull/486  => Shape and move all of the remaining tests to the test-suite folder

This PR follows refactor-vending-minter
1) In refactor-vending-minter organized the tests for vending-minter so that the setup code is separated out
2) In this PR create folder "testing-suite" in which all the tests will eventually go for launchpad

In this PR only doing this for sg-eth-airdrop and vending-minter. There will be another PR where I move the remaining tests in launchpad into testing-suite.

candidates.title: Add executor to splits
candidates.body: An executor can be a member of the group, any address, or `None`. A zero weight member can also be an executor. This is useful for bots. i.e: A bot tied to a cron job that calls `distribute()` periodically.

candidates.title: Refactor Vending Minter Tests
candidates.body:
PART 1
There are 3 PRs in this series: 
1) https://github.com/public-awesome/launchpad/pull/479  => Refactors the vending minter tests that will serve as the common core for other similar tests
2) https://github.com/public-awesome/launchpad/pull/483  => Create the test-suite folder where all tests will eventually go and move the two contracts affected most to the test-suite
3) https://github.com/public-awesome/launchpad/pull/486  => Shape and move all of the remaining tests to the test-suite folder

Motivation: In the sg-eth-airdrop PR I had to borrow a good amount of the code for the vending minter tests.  Since I did a refactor there, figure I would continue on to the source and do some refactoring here. This idea later evolved into sharing all of the commonly reused code for a test-suite folder (developed in parts 2 and 3). 
 
 1) The main feature added here is the `configure_minter` function. The interface of the function looks like so: 
 ```rs
 pub fn configure_minter(
    app: &mut StargazeApp,
    minter_admin: Addr,
    collection_params_vec: Vec<CollectionParams>,
    minter_instantiate_params_vec: Vec<MinterInstantiateParams>,
) -> Vec<MinterCollectionResponse> {
```
2) configure_minter takes two vectors, 1) a vector of collection parameters for providing whichever collections should be tied to minters and 2) a vector of MinterInstantiateParams which contain some settings when instantiating a minter (such as minter start time or splits address). Since vectors are provided, a dev could instantiate any number of minter contracts tied to collections (this may be useful in marketplace if we want to quickly instantiate a whole list of collections). 
3) `configure_minter` returns a vector of `MinterCollectionResponse` objects. The message looks like so: 
```rs
pub struct MinterCollectionResponse {
    pub minter: Option<Addr>,
    pub collection: Option<Addr>,
    pub factory: Option<Addr>,
    pub error: Option<Error>,
}
```
In this way, a developer can call configure minter and get back the minter, factory and collection addresses for each one that is generated in the test. 
4) The error return of `MinterCollectionResponse` allows a dev to peer into any errors returned quickly without special logic. In the following example we try to generate a collection before genesis time and get an error:
```rs
    let minter_collection_response: Vec<MinterCollectionResponse> = configure_minter(
        &mut router,
        creator.clone(),
        vec![collection_params.clone()],
        vec![minter_params],
    );

    let err = minter_collection_response[0]
        .error
        .as_ref()
        .unwrap()
        .root_cause();
    let expected_error = ContractError::BeforeGenesisTime {};
 ```

candidates.title: Update to v0.21.5 and update publish script
Use Launchpad Whitelist Generic
candidates.body:
We were using the generic whitelist from names before, then I implemented a version in Launchpad. 

This PR is just to plug in the generic whitelist to the airdrop contract.

candidates.title: Move generic whitelist to launchpad
candidates.body:
We need a whitelist for the Levana contract that can add and remove addresses.  This version works with strings instead of adddresses since we need to do this for Ethereum addresses that can't be validated in CosmWasm. 

I previously implemented this in names, copying the name minter whitelist. I wanted to move this to Launchpad but couldn't do it bc of too many conflicts. Now with more knowledge of Rust and the codebase was able to implement it.

candidates.title: Multiple Operators for Collections Whitelist
candidates.body:
For the Levana project, we need the collection whitelist to have multiple operators/admins such that the airdrop contract will be able to add members to the whitelist. 

This PR implements multiple PRs following the example from marketplace. The other way to implement multiple admins would be to copy the example in cw-plus.

candidates.title: sg-eth-airdrop
candidates.body:
Note: This PR was the parent branch for multiple admins for collection whitelist, which was needed in order for the airdrop contract to modify the collection whitelist. 

*Code Review Update*:
After the code review I made the requested changes: 
1) Changed all .unwrap( ) methods to ? operator. 
2) Validation on min and max air drop fee
3) Fairburn and instantiation fees
4) Whitelist generic was changed to whitelist-immutable, only storing addresses and counts but with no way to modify them once it has been instantiated. This module is covered with tests for the new/reduced functionality. 
5) Validation functions have all been moved to validate? methods that bubble error up to response.
6) Created a lib.rs in each folder, then did pub use::{< functions >} to export desired modules

Goal of this PR was to write the part of the airdrop in which a user gets added to a whitelist but a myriad of other changes were required: 
- copy and refactor unit tests structure from vending-minter
-  mock contracts in unit tests
- multiple admins for collection whitelist
- file structure organization

This PR will get merged into [humanalgorithm/levana-airdrop-contract-2](https://github.com/public-awesome/launchpad/tree/humanalgorithm/levana-airdrop-contract-2) which already had a working payment of airdrop funds. Adding to the collection was the complex part of this project which is why this PR got to its size.
